Another team of has-been/never-was developers (but shrewd profiteers!) tell people they're crowdfunding a nostalgic "spiritual successor" to their 20+ year old space shooter that inexplicably became a minor hit back in the day. Ok, so this being a teaser for an early access you would expect a few problems...I have found only two so far.

The first was a strange performance issue, only on the tutorial level.  When starting I decided to do a 180 and look behind me, the frame rate tanked and I could not see any reason why.  I have since played the whole tutorial, the demo level and a few runs of the "hoard" mode.  Not had this anywhere else, just that one spot in the tutorial.

The second issue is with the controls, right now I have only tried with my Razer Sabertooth (basically an XBOX 360 pad) and it felt horrible - that could just be me though.  Time to break out the Saitek X52 (which is what I played Descent 3 with) and see if it's better (probably will be).

However, even with those minor glitches, this game FELT like Descent!  Even Descent 3 didn't feel like Descent (please do NOT bring that awful Guide Bot back!).  Cracking game, and my short stint in the teaser has convinced me...getting the full game (early access or not).  If, like me, you remember the first Descent fondly, then I think your gonna love this game!

Plays very good, really fun, sort of like FORSAKEN, i waited for somethin like this for ages, and here we go, it's amazing.

Pros: - modernized, but still hardcore and takes skill to survive
- responsive controls, easy to drive, and reliable, joystick or keyboard and mouse, or even x360 controller all are perfect
- well optimized - on FX8 @ 4.4 and RX470 Sapphire Nitro+ 4GB OC @ 1350mhz i get with AO/AA/shadows down - 135-144fps average.
- great graphics since teaser 1.0 - polished and more brutal than ever.
- replay value - will appeal to oldschool fans of descent, but also is now very try-able for modern gamers.
- file size - only 400mb or so! That's great considering a lot of AAA titles nowadays are like well over 4gb.


Cons:
-you need to run in exclusive fullscreen to get full performance, default mode is sort of a windowed which drops a lot of fps in windows10 due to windows 10 desktop vsync.
- It runs on Unity which is not best engine, but hope devs finish it as it already performs nearly perfectly.

Anyone who loved oldschool 6d0f games would/should be happy to try this little demo.

30543873.review:
I loved this demo, but the full game is still in early access, so I encourage caution before buying. The one thing the Demo proves is that the core gameplay is good. But aspects of it may change, or the level design might not be up to par in the full size levels. Or they might suddenly drop Linux support, although the presence of an actual Linux Demo is encouraging. 

So, about this demo:
Played this on Linux with my Saitek Cyborg Evo joystick that I recently bought used. I used the Keyboard for lateral movement. So WASD for forwards backwards and to the sides and Left-SHIFT and Space for up and down. Roll I bound to joystick twist. Deadzone I set to none.

With this Joystick the controls are a dream, the music is perfect and the opressive underground atmosphere all collaborate to make this short demo an experience I played through more than once, and had very much fun each time even though the demo is very short.

I have no idea if it would be as fun with a mouse though, or even a gamepad. 

To reiterate, I still urge caution with early access titles but this demo does prove they have nailed the core gameplay. As always, early access means things might change. Also, the price for the full game is steep for an early access title, early access pretty much means they expect you to do the work of a beta tester, only instead of getting paid for it YOU have to pay. I don't mind helping beta test a game that I get for less than the final price, but considering the hours you put into figuring out how to replicate bugs you find and write useful bug reports, the early access discount for this game is very bad pay. This is of course true for most Early access titles, not just this one.

Все началось с того, как мне попался диск с Descent 2 Maximum для Playstation когда-то давным-давно. Перед этим я уже успел обробовать Disruptor и Final DooM, и Descent был чем-то совсем непохожим на них, присутствовала в нем некая загадочность. В отличие от двух названных игр, эта была "намного более" трехмерной - модельки роботов и сами уровни имели воистину трехмерный дизайн, который и в множестве современных игр нечасто встретишь (я про дизайн уровней:) ). 

Каждый уровень был большим лабиринтом, в котором легко запутаться, с кучей врагов, больше остальных раздражали Thief (такой шустрый робот, который может воровать у вас почти любое снаряжение, вроде б даже оружие может утащить и приходится гоняться за ним по уровню, чтобы вернуть добро обратно себе) и красный "толстяк" стреляющий Homing Missile, от которых хрен увернешься, только если стены не примут в себя их удар:).

Я из тех людей, которые считают, что серия Descent заслуживает не меньшей славы, чем Doom, Quake и другие известные серии игр.
Эта демка довольно похожа на "тот самый Descent", надеюсь что и полноценная игра будет не хуже, и о ней узнают многие.

30376216.review:
"This is not the Descent successor you're looking for"

...the fate of every 6DOF shooter, being compared to Descent. But it actually seems rather competent. Graphics are simplistic but may work very well in VR, controls are simple and responsive, weapons are fun, performance is great, music has a slight Descent vibe ... with the addition of multiplayer and a level editor AFTER release it's certainly gonna be a decent 6DOF arcade experience.

However,
Descent was originally designed as a Doom killer and as such was pretty dark and gritty. Overload - similar to D3 - is very bright and colorful in comparison. Similarly the bots look more like average SHMUP enemies than evil machinery, their shrieking is kind of weak, the music could use a bit more punch ... I'm not getting that same feeling I get from D1 & D2. :(

I'm also not entirely convinced about the level geometry. Everything seems to be on a grid and I wonder if that's a limitation in their engine design. I hope not, but that should only concern people who really want to get creative.

It might not be Descent, but it's still a decent 6DOF shooter. And who knows what happens after the release of some editing tools.

30346394.review:
Descent 3 is one of my favorite games of all time (alongside BG II and Homeworld), so take this review as heavily biased.

In that sense, however, I can say this demo absolutely felt like Descent. From the ship movement to the weapons, fire rates, and enemy behaviors, it's like playing Descent 4. Similtaniously made me nostalgic, and the higher difficulties showed me how much these modern games have seriously dulled my skills. How long has it been since I had to replay the opening level of a game a half dozen times to beat it? I don't even know.

I heard about the kickstarter, but I never put much stock into it and decided to wait and see. So far I am sufficiantly happy with what's been shown here.

I can give some critiques though. It's hard to know if these will have any bearing on the game, but: It's short. Very short. I hope it is just demo short, but it seems to imply this is a full level from the game. Even for a starter level, it felt tiny compared to maps on Dsc3 (or Dsc1 and Dsc2).

While there was a keycard to unlock a single door, it didn't really open up a massive segment of the map like they did on the old games. Again, maybe it's just because it's a demo, maybe it's just the very first level from the game, but it lowered my expectations for a return to form in quality non-linerar map design.

I was happy to see a score page with how many secret areas I found (less than half) and how many items I had found. A nice touch for replayability. Now to see if the game lets you stock weapons and upgrades from level to level, or if you lose them all when you die and have to find them again. The demo only has you start over, which at least is a nice change from the complete lack of a fail state in most games these days.

I also played it with the Steam Controller and in 21:9 and had a blast. I've been wanting to try out Dsc3 with it for a while, but didn't want the hassle of trying to get it to run. Playing with the gyro for pitch and yaw, the joystick for fore/aft and strafe, roll on the bumpers and verticality on the grips, was nearly as much fun as I had with a sidewinder pro back in the day.

29469830.review: This has been a great demo. I have not had this much fun or been challenged so desperately to survive in a very long time. Overload is the next True Six-Degrees of Freedom shooter. Made by the original developers of Decent (the 90's 6-DOF shooter), this new "Revival" of their once great gameplay mechanics and intense level designs has made me giddier than a schoolgirl. The demo is well designed and showcases their classic style of movement and solid gunplay in highly revitalized and gorgeous graphical tech. Some people may be skeptical of flying though tightly designed levels with little more to do then destroy, destroy, destroy. Sure, the aged style of gameplay and lack of miscellaneous objectives that will be present will not engage all audiences; However- with that being said, Doom 2016 is the classic style of Doom gunplay and level design that has once again captured the fun and challenge of the original arena style shooters. So it is with Overload. This game will ensare the visual and auditory senses and create a level of suspense and thrill through complex movement, tight gunplay, and well constructed levels that enhance and challenge both the movement and gunplay in a way that is not present in most modern shooters. While I obviously am a sucker for the classics, I feel I can safely say this game will please most audiences looking for a new tight knit shooter. I encourage all reading this review to try the demo and stick with it for an hour to get comfortable with the controls and have a blast in challenge mode. Hope you all will enjoy it as much as I did and thanks for reading my review!

29215104.review:
For a teaser It's pretty enjoyable.

Everything about this game screams Descent! (Which isn't surprising seeing as how it's made by the same developers as the original Descent series)

It's like Descent with a good spit shine, it plays like a fan of the old series would expect. For those who aren't familliar with such an old game, let me attempt to describe it to you.

The whole experience is chaos from start to finish. You Pilot a big clunky vehicle through the tight coridors of an abandond mine now over run with man slaying robots with 100% free roam controll of your cameras orientation.

Meaning you can fly upside down, back ways, front ways, slant ways and any other ways you can think of! 

And in an old school run and gun coridor shooter style you get to play with plenty of fun guns, bombs, and other power ups to "dispose of" your enemies with. Which is useful because there are more variations of robots than there are weapons to install on your ship

In short, it's simply fun, and I definitely reccomend anyone giving it a try. 

Besides, it's free.

Carbon copy of Decent 1, and that's a GOOD thing. Even the weapons are mostly the same (albeit with different names)

Very promising gameplay, smooth FPS (capped at 60?! if so, why?!), great visuals to the robots and wepons, however the environment is very...grey, currently.

I'd love to see some destruction of the surrounding rock as well as applied damage to robots dependant on where they are hit (armor plates, perhaps a weapon of theirs flying off). What realism that could offer (and joy!) as your wepons shred all in front of you!

Also, the Headlights are...an interesting addition considering we still have flares. Initially I didn't see any reason to turn them off, yet I did since a dark area being lit takes away any fear factor of dark areas and corners that Descent 1&2 could never bring.

The spaces also seem cramped compared to some of the spaces from D1. Whilst tunnels are a staple of the franchise, even the 'open' areas in the demo seems somewhat..small. OR the ship is too big. Who knows!

Honestly though, this will be a fast-paced, fun game when it comes out, I just hope we'll have more vibrant scenery when it does..

25606164.review:
Descent is dead. Long live Descent.

Behold, Overload, the true heir to the 6 DOF shooter that defined my childhood gaming experience.

Buckle up, Material Defender, because Overload will bring your memories of 1998 into the present faster than you can escape an imminent mine collapse.

This game looks great. The devs have lovingly brought the enemy character design from Descent and Descent 2 into 2016. The enemies are new, but it's easy to see their ancestral heredity. It's in their angles, proportions, eyes, and movement.

The lighting is nice, and way more dynamic than the Descent series'.

Why am I comparing Overload, a demo from 2016, to Descent, a game trilogy from the 90s?

Mostly because Overload "feels" the same. It has swoopy, rolling dogfights in confined spaces, an interesting set of powerful weapons, and enough demo gameplay for a few hours. It's enough time to get the feeling back, and made me hungry for more gameplay.

I only wish that the death animation was slightly shorter, or different. Yes, I know I'm dead. Can I stop spinning, and just get back to playing more?

23873901.review:
This is the game that will bring popularity back to the 6DOF genre. This playable teaser gives a feeling that the game has been tested in the way of gameplay because the gampleay feels smooth and challenging but not impossible. This is going to be the successor to Descent and by this teaser it is already obvious that it will turn out better than the current installment of Mechwarrior. This game also doesn't stray too far from the style of Descent and shows it in this teaser where you have 3 enemy types, four maps, five primary weapons, and four missile types. The primary weapons are comparable to those in Descent:
[olist]
[*]Impulse: Similar to the lasers but as of now there are no damage or quad upgrades
[*]Driller: Similar to the Gauss Cannon of Descent 2. Probably one of my favorite weapons
[*]Flak Cannon: This one isn't similar to any Descent weapons but could be closest to the Vulcan but it seems to be a very close range ballistic weapon with high spread and fire rate.
[*]Vortex: Similar to the Spreadpulse. Shoots three bolts in a rotating line.
[*]Thunderbolt: This is identical to the Fusion Cannon. Charge it up and deal a lot of damage.
[/olist]
And for the missiles you have:
[olist]
[*]Falcons: These are basically concussion missiles, a basic dumbfire missile.
[*]Hunters: The name might be incorrect but they are homing missiles that fire in pairs.
[*]Creepers: These are like Smart Mines, if smart mines moved to enemies and had shot velocity.
[*]Devastator: Closest to the Mega missile but doesn't seem to have as large of a blast radius.
[/olist]
So now that the weapons are covered let's talk about the graphics

The game runs in Unity 5 and uses DirectX 11 which by hearing Unity a person could expect lackluster graphics or a really bad framerate. When I first looked at the youtube video of this game it looked like they were using the Unreal Engine but to my surpirse Unity is used and it runs well while still looking great. With my GTX650Ti I can get 40-60 fps with max graphics and only turning ambient occlusion off. So the graphics are great, the game runs great, and the level design is very reminiscent of Descent 1 except the rock faces don't have to be blocky due to better technology and whatnot.

In conclusion, this game is likely to turn out to be very, very good and the only move regarding the way people are able to support the project that could be made to better the popularity and possibly increase support is to make it possible to pay for it through Steam. If this change was made, I believe that more funding would come by people seeing it on steam, having money in their steam wallet, and thinking "why not."

22401368.review:
I downloaded Descent 1 shareware edition from a BBS. I had to ask the BBS owner special access rights for the files. Then I had to beg my parents to leave the phone alone so my download wouldn't be interrupted. Then I waited for hours as the 6 whopping megabytes (!) were being sucked through that little copper wire. And boy, was it worth it!

How things have changed. I clicked "download" on Steam, waited 2 minutes for the 600Mb teaser to install, and I was ready to play. And boy, how things remained the same!

This is Descent all over, but that's not all good. We're in a new millenium now, and we do expect a bit more.

1) The lighting of the levels is exactly as it was 20 years ago: all dark gray, with some lights thrown in at odd angles. No volumetric light, no fog, very little dynamic lighting. Crank it up guys, I want explosions to light those rooms up! I want sparks bouncing off my monitor!
2) The enemies so far seem pretty dumb and follow a recipe that's 20 years overcooked: see player, make warning noise, approach player, shoot once every while. Wolfenstein did that, so did Doom 1, 2 and Descent 1. That was a time when precious CPU cycles had to be spent on graphics. These days, I have CPU cores idling and begging for smarter enemies! Give us AI! Give us sneaky backstabbing bots! Give us cooperative swarms! And my pet peeve in all shooters: give us enemies that PULL THAT TRIGGER as long as they see the player! What enemy is going to release their trigger just to prance around a bit? Make their guns a bit weaker for balance if you have to, but MAKE THEM USE IT!
3) The levels I've seen so far are entirely static. I can practically see the vertices of the mesh. If my ship is a converted mining operator, I would've really liked to dig some new holes. At the very least, shooting my "digger", my lasers or the rockets should have *some* effect to the walls. Apart from a few "scorched" marks, that's probably not going to happen because it would require a rewrite of the engine and a redesign of the levels. Oh well.
4) If a bot charges into me, surely that should impact my camera, my trajectory, my rotation! None of the bots seem to have any weight to them. All animations seem entirely static, just like 20 years ago. Add some rigidbody physics please. Even if a rocket impact doesn't kill them, it should at least toss them around a little bit (that would be a reason for them to release their trigger temporarily). Hitting them with lasers should also send them spinning. Heck, getting hit should send us spinning as well! The lasers should blind us, too. Getting hit needs to be scary! 
5) Aiming with a joystick or a gamepad is always a bit difficult for me. I used to play with mouse and keyboard but this time I'm trying the gamepad. I'll need to practice more before I know whether I like the gamepad.
6) music is MIDI synth straight from the 80's. I wouldn't mind something with more oomph.
7) sound effects seem to have been copied from the Descent 1 project folder. Give us more echo, more ricochet, more stereo, more surround, make us hear the debris around us!
8) we're in the future, but our ship couldn't have a litlte rearview mirror? Really? ;-)

It's not all bad, though!
6) As in the earlier Descent, the levels are wonderfully desorienting. Up is left, right becomes down, forward twists up, down twists backwards. This room looks familiar. Maybe I was here upside down? Love it!
7) My heart started pumping when that little yellow bot charged straight at me! And boy, was it difficult to strafe out of the path of destruction and at the same time get my crosshairs trained on that overactive little bugger for long enoug to shred it to pieces. And BOY, did it feel good when I finally got it!
8) yup, it still feels good to jet forward on full thrusters, guns blazing, rockets lighting up the twisting tunnels and not care about scraping my ship against the dirty rocky walls. This is flying, baby! Bring it on!
9) my little Athlon X2 with 4g RAM and NVidia 650ti runs this teaser beautifully. I'll definitely continue to play this until the final game comes out!

21831381.review:
I've cherished my memories of Descent I and II from the very first time I played the demo on a Best Buy computer. Winding through twisted passageways filled with demented robots around every corner, pulse pounding as you try to peer around the next bend only to hear the lockon of a homing missle from a red hulk that snuck around behind you somehow or was behind a door you just triggered, these types of thrilling moments had me on the edge of my chair the entire time I was playing those games. Throw in the six degrees of freedom and it's like playing Quake or Doom but unchained, where movement in any direction is possible and fighting takes on a whole new level of skill. Suddenly ceilings or walls become floors and up or down become relative. Which really sucks when you have an entire twisty spiderwebbed level to traverse to find the exit door after blowing a reactor. 

All of these things play through my head when I think of Descent. I was a part of the Descent:Underground kickstarter and look forward to great things from that side of the house. These are the original guys however that first blew my mind with the genre defining game. After playing just the demo, I can say it feels like I'm back in that first great trip through the mines again! There aren't many bots, but they are unique and menacing. There aren't many weapons, but they each feel different and purposeful. The areas in the demo aren't large but they are interesting. Most importantly though, I just love playing it! I could and probably will sit and play the challenge mode for hours on end over the coming months. Sure it has bugs, but for a pre-alpha demo it's suprisingly well put together. The challenge mode has same appeal of UberMosh or old school Unreal Tournament to me. Jump in a challenge on hard for just a couple matches after work to destress and see how well you do.

I can't wait until the full game is released, certainly this is one for any Descent fan to be excited about!

21829812.review:
TLDR: Awesome demo, with one or two missteps. 5-20 minutes of fun for free, I recommend.

The game is slightly disorienting but it's got some real potential. I rather enjoyed my five minutes of zero-G dogfighting, and I hope to see the game come out swinging when it releases.

The good:
1: Movement. As the game says, you can move freely in any direction you please. the experience is like flying a space helicopter with no set up or down. The game will orient you somewhat, helping to keep you in line with walls and floors, which is really helpful. In addition, all enemies will orient themselves to match you, which makes them easy to swiftly recognize and fire on.
2: Mechanics. I will admit, the system of grabbing powerups and weapons feels a little old-school, but the weapons themselves aren't bad. Though the driller wasn't particularly exciting, the flak gun was fun, and Lightning felt badass. The explosives were slightly more confusing, as I had no idea what a 'creeper' was (It seemed to be a sort of grenade, so I ended up panic-spamming it a lot) but they felt alright.
3: Presentation. This is a pre-alpha teaser, and as such it didn't have to look amazing, but looking at the enemy ships (Robots?) gave it a good sense of style, and the effects looked pretty nice. And this is only pre-alpha. If the art keeps improving, it'll look great!

The bad:
1: The reticle. It's rare to have an element of the UI affect the gameplay, but the reticle (The 'aiming crosshairs', for those who don't know) got in my way a bit. The shape was helpful is figuring out how my primary weapon's shots would land, but the lines were thick and bright enough that looking past them to see threats in the distance was rough. It's not a big deal in many of the more confined corridors, but there was at least one or two dogfights where I wanted to turn it off. In the end, it's a small, easy fix that ought to be fixed fast.
2: Weapons satisfaction. I know it might not be true that EVERY weapon in a game is satisfying to use, but a few of the weapons' sounds, effects, and function weren't super fun. Particularly thinking of the driller and the falcon missiles. Not a big deal, as there's enough other guns to find and test out (Flak is fun, guys. Find it, try it, celebrate the fourth of july.) that you'll have fun.
3: Lack of direction/instruction. This didn't affect me a WHOLE lot, but it was pretty easy to get lost in some of these levels, and though I think the tutorial map told you about the driller, there weren't a lot of tooltips for the weapons, telling you what they do and such. The starter gun, driller, and flak all function as machine gun weapons, but the lightning gun is a charge weapon reminiscent of a megabuster. The falcon, hunter, and presumably devastator are all rockets, but the creepers are grenades. They might not've been hard to use, but a little blurb about them in the menus or a more dedicated tutorial would help. Certainly, the tutorial helps you move around, but it doesn't teach you much about the weapons or the objectives. I personally had no idea what the reactor was, or how to destroy it when I tried that mode, and though I found and killed it by trial and error (And luckily found the emergency exit BEFORE I messed with the reactor) I wasn't sure if I was supposed to just blast away or do something nuanced, like shoot at the 'eye'. (PS, the answer is blast away. It's not obvious, since most weapons don't immediately rip it up, but just keep shooting. Or better yet, explosive spam.) It seems like a big problem, but again, it ought to be an easy fix.

The neutral:
This game is definitely better with a gamepad. Just be ready to mess with your bindings, I personally found X/A to rotate and LT/LB to raise/lower to be a bit weird, and I honestly need to swap it.

Verdict: It's not perfect, and there's some work to be done, but trust me: It's not bad. It's just a quick free demo to show off the mechanics, and it was kinda fun. Slightly disorienting, but fun for sure. Just grab the fun guns and go to town for a few minutes. Would I recommend this if it were a full game? Maybe not. Would I say it's a great demo/teaser, and it's made me intrigued to see how the full game turns out? Hell yes. I mean, it's free, and it's like ten minutes of your time. Go for it!

21790635.review:
Slow. You move slow, the enemy moves slow, combat feels slow with huge slow bullets and spongey enemies.

Floaty sluggish controls, almost a half second lag between mouse and screen movment, gives the feeling of a drunken underwater dream. Lots of weird acceleration and momemtum going on. Even when you learn to compensate it's still annoying.

Poor level design - many identical gray caves with no clues to orientation or location. Very difficult to navigate, orientate or find anything. No map, no guidebot.

FoV is adaquate but could use a little more. No way to adjust.

Didn't crash. Lighting is good. Sound is ok but unexciting. Textures are ok but unexciting.

I'm mean because I care, all this is fixable! The game has great potential!

It's a fine tech demo, just needs lots and lots of tuning to make it a proper game.

21744063.review:
My god, I never dreamed this would exist. Never! It's modern Descent! Like from very early stages, it just oozes that same sort of atmospheric feel to it that drew me into gaming as a kid. The twisting pathways, the frentic combat, THE LIGHTING OH MAN HAS MODERN TECH REALLY IMPROVED THAT WOW, even the weapons feel right at home with the classic dual lasers, the spread cannon (Vortex), and fusion cannon (Thunderbolt) making near picture perfect returns. The updated gauss cannon (Driller) feels a LOT better than the original with that slow ROF, high impact feel that lets you know in not so many words (well, details?) that you're downranging some real hefty payload. The robot designs are spot-on; already that buzzsaw robot has got me scrambling to dodge and keep it at bay with just its alarming screech. My answer? A quick swap to the new Flak Cannon and shotgun the hell out of it! Level design has been excellent so far; nothing to note there like it's just perfect and the lighting, again, just enhances it to incredible levels, A+ work there. Speaking of lighting, whoever decided that yes the headlight shouldn't consume energy, you are my hero. Always did bug me when I'm trying to conserve gauss ammo and I drain myself of energy reeeeeaaal fast running headlight AND AB AND lasers/helix. ALSO CHALLENGE MODE. Please, I sincerely hope this stays in on release because that is a boundless source of fun right there. Non-stop enemies, never knowing which way they'll spawn in next, and constantly feeling the pressure of your dwindling resources? SOLD, SIGN ME UP.

If I had the money right now, I'd so back this and then buy another copy for my father. I know for a fact he'd enjoy the hell out of it because he's the one who got me hooked on 6DOF back in the day to begin with.

If you've watched the teaser videos, maybe even played the teaser a bit and you're still on the fence about all of this, pick up Descent 1-3 here on Steam, look up the modern day patches for them, and delve even deeper into 6DOF. If Descent gets you hooked (and trust me, I'm not just looking through rose-colored lenses here, the gameplay definitely still holds up!), then please back this!

21741463.review:
Very pleasant.  This was my first 6DX (I think that's what it's called) game.  I was very pleased with the game and how it played out.  I am very interested to see where this will go from here, but I do see a few faults to the game.  We'll talk about that later.

Also, before we get into the review, the buttons on the mouse sensitivity options don't work (had to use keyboard).

Pros:

-Fun
-DOOM-esque atmosphere (I like)
-DOOM-esque gameplay elements such as health and weapon pickups (works to the game's advantage)
-Good weapon variety for what we were given
-Solid gameplay
-Interesting enemy variety

Cons:

-Confusing map layout
-Music tends to repeat and sound the same (no offense to the composer)
-Doesn't really seem to matter if you roll around.  It's more advantageous to stay in one position and don't use Q or E (default)
-Enemies look the same with the exception of the asshole with the sawblade (NERF PLOX, DPS TOO HIGH)
-No real manuverability options other than moving side to side and up and down.
-Feels...repetitive and like I don't have a real goal (I forgot what I was doing in "Reactor Destroy").
-Floaty camera movement.  It's weird as fuck.

Opinions and Suggestions:

-Art style doesn't seem to fit the current mood of the game.  Given what I just played, I feel like a more simplistic art style might have worked better for this sort of game, though it's up to you.  I enjoy what I got.
-Minimap.  Doesn't have to display enemies and it doesn't have to be highly detailed.  A top-down view of a grid based map would be alright with me.
-Less claustrophobic spaces please.
-The DOOM music fits the CURRENT mood of the game, but I'd like a little bit more variety rather than just techno all the way through.  May I suggest either a rock or orchestra (if you can afford it of course) cover during boss battles?
-Speaking of boss battles, if you don't think your game is going to be memorable, I suggest making crazy-awesome boss fights.  Something like how Metal Gear Rising Revengence did in their boss fights.  Crazy, over the top, and just plain awesome.  May I suggest: Giant Spaceship with multiple pieces that you have to individually damage that will, over time, break off to reveal a large reactor that you'll have to destroy to beat the boss?
-A default melee weapon or option would be nice.  DOOM had fists and a chainsaw.  I'd like...oh I don't know, "ramming"?  Actually, that sounds pretty useful.  Gives the boost ability a little more strategic worth.
-Sawblade enemy is an asshole (in a good way).
-Can combat be a little bit faster?  Seems slow.
-Hard mouse movement.  I'd like the camera to stop when I stop my mouse.

Final thoughts:

It's a good teaser.  I would rather recommend a complete product though.  I'd tell people to try this game out and see if they like it.  I would also recommend it to people who want to try out this genre.  This would be a good starting point.  It's not crazy difficult but is still hard enough for you to enjoy.

I'm looking forward to the final product.  Good luck.
Sadly, I won't be able to assist you with funding though.

21721474.review:
It's Descent. If you played Descent when you were younger, it's back, proper.
The two designers for the original Descents have made a proper spiritual continuation, it looks and plays exactly as it should; you smash panels and parts off repurposed mining robots until they go fireworks, while they try to extract the meaty bit from your ships metal shell using various methods.

The controls are intuitive, the momentum physics behave as you would expect, the weapons have a solid feel to them (even the frickin laser beams) and each connecting hit gives a physics reaction and a pretty light show as reward.
The sound is great, the baddies sound suitably demonically possessed, the lighting is a real treat, accurate realtime shadows (something of a rarity these days for some reason) are on full display and it all sits together in a surprisingly atmospheric package.

You still get as disorientated as the original Descents and the screen fills with carnage quickly, but that's a positive in this reviewer's book.
The story is to be written by the writer of Freespace 2 and the music is from the original Descent's crew, many Parallax (original Descent) developers are in the team, making this a very exciting project.

Check out the[url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/revivalprod/overload-the-ultimate-six-degree-of-freedom-shoote/description] Kickstarter [/url]for more info, definitely check out the excellent free teaser demo, it's nostalgia redone right.

I welcomed the chance to play another Descent like game.
I have lots of similar titles in my library: Sublevel zero, Retrovirus and of course Descent 1, Descent 2 modified to their DX version to have 1080 graphics. These games all feel like the old descent.
That being said, this game does not feel like Descent at all. The feeling is very similar to the Descent Underground, which I also have, and it feels like instead of a ship you are piloting a tank... that can also fly. The action is not nimble, you are not agile and able to dodge bullets, you just move slowly from side to side while silly robots pretend to shoot at you and miss stormtrooper style. Overload does have something better than Descent Underground, the bots are slightly more intelligent making the single player a bit more interesting. It still falls short of original descents and Sublevel zero or even Retrovirus. I paid 20 EUR for Descent Underground and was dissapointed even though it also claimed to be developed by members of the old Descent team. Therefore I am not going to back Overload in its current state, I will only be dissapointed again.

Suggestions for potential improvements:

Player ship speed should be higher, ships smaller and bullet size smaller so as to make the player able to dodge incoming bullets or charging robots. The player should feel like Neo in Matrix not like a ship in a naval battle.

Focus on gameplay first not on graphics. Yes graphics are important but they don't have to be top notch realistic to get a    good feeling from the game. E.g. Sublevel zero does not have realistic graphics but it is a very nice game.

21714241.review:
There has been many reboots or spiritual successors of many games as of late. Some successfully bring back what made those games great, and some bring new innovations to revitalise the IP. However it is seldom both.

Doom as an example, has gone from its original demon killing fast paced mayham, then a slow paced action horror game which lost all of what originally made it great. That has become clear to the developer, and is now adapting both what made the original great and bringing modern innovations capable in todays gaming.

But why am I talking about Doom, when this is not Doom?
Well, Overload is a perfect example of a developer bringing back what made a game great (Descent) during the same era, and updating it with new innovations.

They have demonstrated in this demo that they are bringing back the fast paced robot destroying action, with the great 6DOF movement that made the original an instant classic, whilst still embracing the innovations in modern gaming.

This demo is a prototype build they have currently made before even being funded to actually produce the game. Yet it feels far more polished than you would expect in those circumstances, with far more enjoyment then you would expect.

I recommend having a play of this demo, and see the potential behind this tiny glimse of what this developer is capable of, and if you like what you see go back the game on kickstarter. Because if this demo can entertain you, imagine what they will produce further with that funding.

Thanks for reading, and I hope you enjoy this hopefully soon to be master piece.

21713782.review:
It’s 1996.  I’m 12, and I’ve just been introduced to Descent II from a friend. We’ve been playing modem 1v1 games, lugging our desktops around for ‘Lan’ games with a serial cable, and recently discovered Kahn and Kali.  For the next 8 years, Descent 1, 2, and 3 consume the vast majority of the time I spend on games.  Heck, I learned so much about networking by setting up LAN events with friends that I get my first job as a network tech at 16.  I’m downloading addon missions, I’m creating my own mines, and I can draw a map of Minerva 3 in my sleep. In 1999 I start writing for Descent3.net, and in 2003 I’m running the top ranked team on the Descent 3 Teams League with my friends ‘Roncli’, ‘Xeon’, and ‘Shadow’.  When I moved to Australia in 2012, my friends and I all got together for a Descent 3 LAN party.  Needless to say, I’m hooked for life.

It took less than 52 seconds to sell me on Overload.  By the end of the video above, I knew this was the real deal – a 6DoF game that feels right – and I haven’t even felt it yet.  The way the ‘bots look, the way the weapons look, the way the mines look, the motion of the ship…in the video at least, they’ve captured the feel of Descent perfectly.  And it makes sense – these are the guys that created Descent – heck, the entire genre.  Hardcore Descent veterans will recognize many (if not all) of the guys on the right!

I've posted about Overload extensively on www.fistsofheaven.com and there are some LetsPlay videos there as well.  This is the game I've been waiting for since Descent 3.  Thanks so much Revival!

21711737.review:
[h1] DESCENT REBORN [/h1]
Now on KikStarter

Overload is the 21st Century rebirth of the classic game Descent. The original devs from Parallax (now Revival Productions) have got the band back together and are using their expert knowledge in the genre and the latest tech to bring the excellent 6DOF shooter back to life.
So has it been a success? From the playable teaser it's fair to say that, so far, it has been an enormous success. Everything about Overload looks and feels like a modern day Descent. Flying through a hollowed out mining asteroid has brought back so many fond memories of my gaming time back in the 90s, it's allowed me to relive those great experiences, and it's put a smile on my face too many times to count. All from just a short playable teaser.

The first obvious improvement from the classic games is the graphics. The most notable enhancement is the dynamic lighting. Watching the light emitted from your impulse energy cannon illuminate the nearby walls gives you that 'wow factor', which makes you end up wasting a ton of ammo just to watch the pretty lights. Ooh! Shiny!

Enemy robots explode in a very satisfying manner. The sound of them "screaming" as bits of their debris go shooting off in various directions is an audio-visual feast. But before this happens you get to admire hunks of metal armour gradually break off from the enemy bots before you can shoot at their exposed inner workings. A lot of this debris is persistent throughout the level making it feel like a true battlegroud where enemies were actually pitted against one another, and not an uninhabited sterile environment.

Enemy robots are also equipped with a high-powered light that they use to their disadvantage in the pitch black, darkened sections of the asteroid. Why is this to their detriment? Because as the light source shifts from one place to another the way it's cast onto surrounding walls allows you to work out, pretty accurately, the direction and distance of your enemy - without having direct line of sight. Advantage player. Like the explosions this is another feast for the eyes to behold, you have to experience it for yourself.


Overall, Overload is a very impressive achievement, but by far the aspect of the game that's most worthy of respect and admiration is the enemy AI. The hostile robots you'll encounter in the asteroid husks are not your typical opponents. Some will just charge straight at you, some will just sit there and aggressively shoot at you with everything they've got, but most (and this is the really good bit) will actually try to dodge your incoming fire. This sense of self-preservation is truly impressive because quite a lot of the time your enemies will succeed in evading your attacks by strafing in the appropriate direction, hiding behind cover, and even running away completely only to reappear a minute later behind you when you suddenly find yourself completely surrounded! In a time where a lot of combat is just point and click or mindless button mashing, this self awareness and teamwork is very much welcomed. You will end up wasting a lot of ammo and/or dying if you're not careful with your tactics.


Reasons to Support Overload:
- Incredibly good AI, which will definitely challenge you.
- Lovely visuals, especially with the dynamic lighting.
- Classic 'destroy the reactor and then run for your life' mode, and an endless challenge mode.
- It's Descent, lovingly made by the people who know the 6DOF shooter genre better than anyone else.


In Summary:

BACK THIS ON KICKSTARTER NOW!

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/revivalprod/overload-the-ultimate-six-degree-of-freedom-shoote?ref=nav_search

Happy shooting :)

21698097.review:
There have been many attempts to rekindle the magic of Descent, the venerable progenitor of the entire 6DoF genre.  Some have been bug-ridden trash, others have been moderately acceptable if lacking polish, and a couple have been well-made but lacking in important features like multiplayer.  But the true look, feel, and pace of the Descent originals have only ever been rivaled by the equally-venerable competitor, Forsaken.  Even the recent entrants to the field, Descent: Underground and Sol Contingency, pay homage to their forebears while not quite adequately delivering the full experience.

And along comes Overload, a game on Kickstarter with the intention of doing just that, coded and produced by the same key players that brought us the original Descent franchise... and you can tell.  This game may not carry the same name (because Interplay owns the name), but the look, sound, and feel are all decidedly Descent in every way.

This is what I've waited for, and it absolutely must be made.  The teaser demo above gives you everything you need to know.  Even in a pre-alpha state, with joystick support almost nonexistent, you can still tell what this is capable of.  If you loved the original games, run (don't walk) to their Kickstarter page and make sure this gets funded.  Right now.

Seriously.  Now.  Go.

EDIT:  Build version 4, which should now be on Steam or will be shortly, fixes all the joystick issues as far as I can tell.

EDIT2:  The Kickstarter got funded!  Keep an eye out in 2017 for the release!  And they've comitted themselves to a multiplayer DLC, so all is right with the world.  See you in the mines.

EDIT3:  It's March of 2017, and on the anniversary of their successful Kickstarter campaign, Revival has released a 2.0 version of their teaser trailer that's positively mouth-watering.  There's not a lot new in terms of level content, but the game runs much better, there's new bots, better AI, and a new HUD that's clearly made to look good and still be VR-friendly.  The company has also notified backers that a Steam Early Access version of the full game will be out later this month, with a few of the levels completed.  Multiplayer is still a ways off, but everything so far continues to give good vibes.  Time for some carnage!
